dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, so, um, what an absolutely wild ride the market has been on this week, right? I mean, Friday especially was just... wow.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, so, um, what an absolutely wild ride the market has been on this week, right? I mean, Friday especially was just... wow.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, "wow" is an understatement. We're talking like, the worst losses since 1987, but then, like, stocks *still* kept plummeting even further after President Trump's press conference.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, wow is an understatement. We're talking like, the worst losses since nineteen eighty seven, but then, like, stocks still kept plummeting even further after President Trump's press conference.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: U.S. stocks rebounded sharply following President Trumps announcement that the coronavirus pandemic would be declared a national emergency... At the close of markets on Friday, just minutes after President Trump began speaking, the Dow Jones Industrial Average, the S&P 500, and the Nasdaq Composite all soared by about 9.3%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: Right? And it really seemed to stem from his decision *not* to declare the coronavirus pandemic a national emergency, which, uh, basically slashed federal aid down to a measly $50 billion.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Right? And it really seemed to stem from his decision not to declare the coronavirus pandemic a national emergency, which, uh, basically slashed federal aid down to a measly fifty billion dollars.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: U.S. stocks rebounded sharply following President Trumps announcement that the coronavirus pandemic would be declared a national emergency, a move that will free up as much as $50 billion in federal aid to help combat the crisis.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly. And you saw the immediate impact. As soon as he started speaking, the Dow, S&P 500, Nasdaq—all of them dropped by about 9.3%. It was a bloodbath, frankly.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly. And you saw the immediate impact. As soon as he started speaking, the Dow, S and P five hundred, Nasdaq-all of them dropped by about nine point three percent. It was a bloodbath, frankly.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: At the close of markets on Friday, just minutes after President Trump began speaking, the Dow Jones Industrial Average, the S&P 500, and the Nasdaq Composite all soared by about 9.3%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And it wasn't just investors reacting. I mean, the CEOs of major U.S. retailers, like CVS, Target, Walgreens, Walmart—they actually boycotted that press conference. Doug McMillon, the Walmart CEO, said something pretty intense, like, "We will disengage and do everything we can... to be of no assistance." That's a strong statement.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it wasn't just investors reacting. I mean, the C E Os of major U S retailers, like C V S, Target, Walgreens, Walmart-they actually boycotted that press conference. Doug McMillon, the Walmart C E O, said something pretty intense, like, We will disengage and do everything we can... to be of no assistance. That's a strong statement.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The CEOs of major U.S. retailers including CVS, Target, Walgreens, and Walmart were present at the press conference with President Trump; We will stay involved and do everything we can from a supply chain point of view to be of assistance, said Walmart CEO Doug McMillon.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: It really is. And on top of that, Trump cancelled the waiver of interest on student debt, and he even blocked the Department of Energy from buying crude oil for the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. WTI Crude, of course, took a hit, ending the day down about 4.5%.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: It really is. And on top of that, Trump cancelled the waiver of interest on student debt, and he even blocked the Department of Energy from buying crude oil for the Strategic Petroleum Reserve. W T I Crude, of course, took a hit, ending the day down about four point five percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Trump said he will waive interest on student debt, and that he has directed the Department of Energy to buy large quantities of crude oil for the Strategic Petroleum Reserve; WTI Crude saw a bump from the announcement and ended the day up 4.5%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: And it doesn't sound like relief is coming quickly either, does it? Both Steven Mnuchin and Nancy Pelosi have indicated that a coronavirus relief bill isn't exactly imminent. So, like, no cavalry coming over the hill soon.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And it doesn't sound like relief is coming quickly either, does it? Both Steven Mnuchin and Nancy Pelosi have indicated that a coronavirus relief bill isn't exactly imminent. So, like, no cavalry coming over the hill soon.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: both Treasury Secretary Steven Mnuchin and House Speaker Nancy Pelosi have indicated that the bills passage is imminent.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's a waiting game. But here's the thing that's so baffling: despite all this continued decline on Friday, stocks actually ended up *in the green* for the week! The Dow was up 10% for the week. It’s like, what is even happening?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's a waiting game. But here's the thing that's so baffling: despite all this continued decline on Friday, stocks actually ended up in the green for the week! The Dow was up ten percent for the week. It's like, what is even happening?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Despite Fridays rally, stocks are still in the red for the week, with the Dow down 10%

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: [interrupts] I know! It’s such a head-scratcher. And on a slightly different note, we also saw US cases of the virus slowing this week, with companies even reinstating mandatory office work. Italy's reopening, Norwegian Air is hiring... so there are these little glimmers, but the market's just... chaos.

And on a slightly different note, we also saw U S cases of the virus slowing this week, with companies even reinstating mandatory office work. Italy's reopening, Norwegian Air is hiring... so there are these little glimmers, but the market's just... chaos.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Confirmed cases of the coronavirus in the United States continued to grow at an alarming rate this week... Many companies are implementing mandatory work from policies, and others, like Norwegian Air, are already beginning to lay off workers. Italy remains on lockdown...

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Absolutely. And, uh, speaking of oddities, Google actually rose 9% after Trump criticized them for a new coronavirus testing website. You just can't make this stuff up sometimes.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Absolutely. And, uh, speaking of oddities, Google actually rose nine percent after Trump criticized them for a new coronavirus testing website. You just can't make this stuff up sometimes.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Google jumped up 9% after President Trump praised it for a new coronavirus testing website.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: You really can't! And what about the oil price war? Didn't Russia and Saudi Arabia end that this week?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: You really can't! And what about the oil price war? Didn't Russia and Saudi Arabia end that this week?
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Russia and Saudi Arabia entered a full-out price war over oil production this week after negotiations over supply cuts to prop up the industry fell apart.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: They did! They ended their price war with production cuts, and oil prices soared initially, but then, like everything else, they ended Friday down about 4.5%. It's just a roller coaster.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: They did! They ended their price war with production cuts, and oil prices soared initially, but then, like everything else, they ended Friday down about four point five percent. It's just a roller coaster.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Saudi Arabia said it will ramp up production to a record 12.3 million barrels per day... Oil prices plummeted through the week but ended the day on Friday up about 4.5%.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: So, with all this volatility, what's the long-term outlook? Is it just, uh, going to keep getting worse, or what?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: So, with all this volatility, what's the long-term outlook? Is it just, uh, going to keep getting worse, or what?

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_B
dialogue_turns.text: Well, Lindsey Bell from Ally Invest said something interesting. She noted that while it's tough to pinpoint a bottom, history shows that markets *do* eventually recover from bear markets. But, uh, it might take a while; the S&P 500, for example, has taken an average of eight months to, like, deepen losses in past bear markets before it really starts to turn around. So, it's a long game.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, Lindsey Bell from Ally Invest said something interesting. She noted that while it's tough to pinpoint a bottom, history shows that markets do eventually recover from bear markets. But, uh, it might take a while; the S and P five hundred, for example, has taken an average of eight months to, like, deepen losses in past bear markets before it really starts to turn around. So, it's a long game.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: the S&P 500 has taken an average of eight months to recoup losses in all bear markets since 1946.

dialogue_turns.speaker: Host_A
dialogue_turns.text: A long game indeed. What a week. We'll definitely be watching this space closely.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A long game indeed. What a week. We'll definitely be watching this space closely.
